question.title: Speed: four ints or one int with many operations

node.contents: There is no "unsigned" in java.

astNode.text: There is no "unsigned" in java.

node.contents: I suppose he means "an int where I ignore the sign-bit".

astNode.text: I suppose he means "an int where I ignore the sign-bit".

node.contents: You're right, I just mean 'int'...

astNode.text: You're right, I just mean 'int'...

node.contents: I guess the question is whether passing 4 arguments incurs a speed penalty over passing 1 argument. I'm inclined to think that the cost of packing your 4 variables into one and then unpacking on the other side would be less efficient than whatever Java does with 4 arguments.

astNode.text: I guess the question is whether passing 4 arguments incurs a speed penalty over passing 1 argument. I'm inclined to think that the cost of packing your 4 variables into one and then unpacking on the other side would be less efficient than whatever Java does with 4 arguments.

node.contents: I have a speed question for Java. I am making a chess program, and I want to check if is a good idea to use one 'int' as a variable to store four 'int' variables, in which the values range from 1 to (4 bits).

astNode.text: I have a speed question for Java. I am making a chess program, and I want to check if is a good idea to use one 'int' as a variable to store four 'int' variables, in which the values range from 1 to (4 bits).

node.contents: The problem is that I'll often have to extract and put in new parts of the variable, so that will cost quite some (bitwise) operations.

astNode.text: The problem is that I'll often have to extract and put in new parts of the variable, so that will cost quite some (bitwise) operations.

node.contents: Code:

astNode.text: Code:

elements.contents: int fromX = 4, fromY = 5, toX = 6, toY = 7; int move = 0 move |= toY; move = move << 4; move |= toX; move = move << 4; move |= fromY; move = move << 4; move |= fromX; doWork(move);

units.rawText: int fromX = 4, fromY = 5, toX = 6, toY = 7; int move = 0 move |= toY; move = move << 4; move |= toX; move = move << 4; move |= fromY; move = move << 4; move |= fromX; doWork(move);

node.contents: or

astNode.text: or

elements.contents: int fromX = 4, fromY = 5, toX = 6, toY = 7; doWork(fromX, fromY, toX, toY);

units.rawText: int fromX = 4, fromY = 5, toX = 6, toY = 7; doWork(fromX, fromY, toX, toY);

node.contents: doWork() will do a lot of different things with the coordinates, mostly extract them from the 'int', or just use the variables.

astNode.text: doWork() will do a lot of different things with the coordinates, mostly extract them from the 'int', or just use the variables.

node.contents: Which should I use?

astNode.text: Which should I use?

node.contents: I have written most of my program, and I don't want to write very big parts of it again. That's why I asked. I'll start profiling in some days, when I finish a major bug. Thanks!

astNode.text: I have written most of my program, and I don't want to write very big parts of it again. That's why I asked. I'll start profiling in some days, when I finish a major bug. Thanks!

node.contents: Very good answer. I agree with each word. I just want to add that the question is the classical example of premature optimisation.

astNode.text: Very good answer. I agree with each word. I just want to add that the question is the classical example of premature optimisation.

node.contents: I want to check if is a good idea to use one 'unsigned int' as a variable to store four 'int' variables

astNode.text: I want to check if is a good idea to use one 'unsigned int' as a variable to store four 'int' variables

node.contents: No, this is a Bad Idea for a bunch of reasons.

astNode.text: No, this is a Bad Idea for a bunch of reasons.

node.contents:
1. This would be highly inefficient

  2. Very hard to read

  3. (consequently) very hard to debug

astNode.text:
1. This would be highly inefficient

  2. Very hard to read

  3. (consequently) very hard to debug

node.contents: Sure, it may save a few bytes here and there, but honestly, I buy my RAM-modules in gigabytes these days.

astNode.text: Sure, it may save a few bytes here and there, but honestly, I buy my RAM-modules in gigabytes these days.

node.contents: My suggestion:

astNode.text: My suggestion:

node.contents: Write up your entire chess-program. If you run into performance problems, profile the program to see where the bottle-necks are, and do something about those. (I can guarantee you that you won't start packing several numbers into an int once you reach this point.)

astNode.text: Write up your entire chess-program. If you run into performance problems, profile the program to see where the bottle-necks are, and do something about those. (I can guarantee you that you won't start packing several numbers into an int once you reach this point.)

node.contents: I really don't want to make any Objects, because anything I do will be reapeated about 10 million times, when searching in my chess-game-possible-move-tree... And the coordinates are not really flags, they change a lot, and are passed back and forth beween methods.

astNode.text: I really don't want to make any Objects, because anything I do will be reapeated about 10 million times, when searching in my chess-game-possible-move-tree... And the coordinates are not really flags, they change a lot, and are passed back and forth beween methods.

node.contents: OK, I see. Then you might want to think about creating a "Context" or "Arguments" - Object once and share that one instance over your 10 gazillion calls ...

astNode.text: OK, I see. Then you might want to think about creating a "Context" or "Arguments" - Object once and share that one instance over your 10 gazillion calls ...

node.contents: If you just want to store some Flags, you can use BitSet for example. If it is data, I second aioobe's answer.

astNode.text: If you just want to store some Flags, you can use BitSet for example. If it is data, I second aioobe's answer.

node.contents: As Alan Kay said,

astNode.text: As Alan Kay said,

node.contents: "Make it work, make it correct, make it fast, make it cheap"

astNode.text: "Make it work, make it correct, make it fast, make it cheap"

node.contents: Once you've got the program working, measure it to find out what's slow, or what takes too much space. You can then make a reasoned decision about what you need to optimise.

astNode.text: Once you've got the program working, measure it to find out what's slow, or what takes too much space. You can then make a reasoned decision about what you need to optimise.
